title: RS21344
content: The European Union (EU) is a partnership among 28 member states focused on peaceful integration through enlargement. This process has helped former dictatorships and communist states become stable democracies and market economies. The EU keeps the door open for any European country, like Turkey and the Western Balkans, that meets its political and economic criteria. The EU's enlargement policy has been a powerful tool in transforming former dictatorships and communist states into stable democracies and market economies. The EU remains open to any European country meeting its criteria for membership, with Croatia being the newest member. However, there are concerns that EU enlargement may be reaching its limits due to financial troubles and waning public enthusiasm for further expansion. The EU's enlargement policy has successfully transformed former dictatorships and communist states into stable democracies and market economies. Croatia joined the EU in 2013, but there are concerns about the limits of further expansion due to financial troubles and waning public enthusiasm. The EU's economic woes and uncertainty about its future direction may make joining the Union less attractive for some potential candidates. The EU's enlargement policy has transformed former dictatorships and communist states into stable democracies and market economies. Financial troubles and uncertainty about the EU's future direction may hinder further expansion. EU leaders need to focus on internal issues to prevent obstacles to the enlargement agenda. The European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was established in 1952 by six states to create a single market in coal and steel industries. This was a key stage in the process of European integration aimed at promoting peace, stability, and economic growth in Europe after World War II. In 1952, six states established the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) to create a single market in coal and steel industries. This integration project aimed to control raw materials of war, promote economic interdependence, and prevent future conflicts in Europe. In 1957, the ECSC member states signed treaties in Rome to establish the European Economic Community (EEC) for common economic policies and merging national markets. In 1957, the six ECSC member states signed two new treaties in Rome: the first established the European Economic Community (EEC) to develop common economic policies and merge national markets into a single market; the second created a European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) for peaceful nuclear energy use. These treaties, known as the "Treaties of Rome," came into force in 1958. The Treaties of Rome in 1957 established the European Economic Community (EEC) to create a single market and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) for peaceful nuclear energy use. In 1967, the ECSC, EEC, and EURATOM became the European Community (EC). The EC expanded with new members in 1973, 1981, and 1986. The Single European Act in 1987 modified the EC treaties to facilitate the single market and introduce institutional reforms. The European Community (EC) was formed from the ECSC, EEC, and EURATOM. New members joined in 1973, 1981, and 1986. The Single European Act in 1987 facilitated the single market and increased the powers of the European Parliament. The completion of the single market in 1993 allowed for free movement of goods, people, capital, and services. The Treaty on European Union (Maastricht Treaty) came into effect on November 1, 1993. The Maastricht Treaty in 1993 established the modern-day European Union with three pillars: an expanded EC, a common foreign and security policy, and common internal security measures. It also led to the creation of an Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). The Maastricht Treaty in 1993 established the modern-day European Union with three pillars: an expanded and strengthened EC, a common foreign and security policy, and common internal security measures. It also led to the creation of an Economic and Monetary Union (EMU), including the euro. Austria, Finland, and Sweden joined the EU on January 1, 1995, bringing membership to 15 member states. EU leaders met in June 1997 to review the Maastricht Treaty. The European Union, established by the Maastricht Treaty in 1993, aimed for greater economic integration and political cooperation. In 1995, Austria, Finland, and Sweden joined, bringing membership to 15 states. The Amsterdam Treaty in 1999 enhanced the EU's legislative powers and foreign policy, while the Nice Treaty in 2000 further integrated internal security policies. In 1997, EU leaders reviewed the Maastricht Treaty and discussed the future of European integration. The resulting Amsterdam Treaty in 1999 enhanced the European Parliament's legislative powers, strengthened foreign policy, and aimed to integrate internal security policies. The Nice Treaty in December 2000 paved the way for EU enlargement, focusing on Eastern Europe, and set out internal reforms for effective operation and new member acceptance. The Nice Treaty, concluded by EU leaders in 2000, aimed to facilitate EU enlargement to Eastern Europe by implementing internal reforms. It extended majority voting in the Council of Ministers and restructured the European Commission to accommodate new members. Since the Cold War, the EU had been assisting former communist countries in Central and Eastern Europe to meet membership criteria. The Nice Treaty in 2000 expanded majority voting in the Council of Ministers and restructured the European Commission to prepare for EU enlargement to Eastern Europe. The EU had been helping former communist countries in Central and Eastern Europe meet membership criteria since the Cold War. Cyprus and Malta also expressed interest in joining the EU, with accession negotiations starting in March 1998. The EU began accession negotiations with several Eastern European countries in order to fulfill a historic pledge to integrate the continent peacefully. Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Poland, and Slovenia started negotiations in March 1998, followed by six others in December 1999: Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Romania, and Slovakia. In December 2001, the EU announced negotiations with 10 countries for membership. The EU initiated accession negotiations with Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Poland, and Slovenia, followed by six more countries in December 1999. By December 2001, negotiations were underway with 10 countries, leading to the conclusion of talks by the end of 2002. Challenges arose during negotiations, particularly regarding agriculture and regional assistance, but a deal was eventually reached with all 10 candidates. The EU concluded accession talks with 10 countries by the end of 2002, addressing issues like agriculture and regional assistance. The accession treaty was signed in April 2003, and the countries joined the EU on May 1, 2004. Bulgaria and Romania completed negotiations in December 2004, despite concerns about judicial reforms and anti-corruption efforts. The EU concluded accession talks with 10 countries in December 2002, signing the accession treaty in April 2003. Bulgaria and Romania joined the EU in January 2007, and Croatia acceded in July 2013, bringing the total member states to 28. The Union's borders now stretch from the Baltics to the Black Sea, with a population exceeding 500 million. Bulgaria and Romania joined the EU on January 1, 2007, followed by Croatia on July 1, 2013, bringing the total member states to 28. The EU's borders now extend from the Baltics to the Black Sea, with a population exceeding 500 million. Critics of the Nice Treaty argued that it created a more complex and less efficient decision-making process, potentially limiting the EU to 27 member states. The Nice Treaty faced criticism for creating a complex and inefficient decision-making process, potentially limiting the EU to 27 member states. In response, the EU initiated institutional reforms leading to the Lisbon Treaty coming into force on December 1, 2009, after the rejection of the proposed EU constitutional treaty in 2005. The EU embarked on institutional reform efforts in 2002, leading to the Lisbon Treaty coming into force on December 1, 2009. The treaty aims to streamline governing institutions, eliminate hurdles to EU enlargement, and strengthen the EU's global presence. The Lisbon Treaty, implemented in 2009, aims to streamline EU institutions, remove barriers to enlargement, and enhance the EU's global influence. It also focuses on increasing democracy and transparency by empowering the European Parliament and setting criteria for new member states. The Maastricht Treaty outlines criteria for EU membership, including stability of institutions, democracy, rule of law, human rights, market economy, and adherence to EU aims. The criteria for EU membership include stability of institutions guaranteeing democracy, rule of law, human rights, and a functioning market economy. The EU must also be able to absorb new members and evaluate their readiness for membership. EU enlargement is a complex technical and political process. EU enlargement is a complex process involving adherence to political, economic, and monetary union aims. Membership criteria include stability of institutions, democracy, human rights, and a functioning market economy. The EU decides when to accept new members, with the process requiring unanimous agreement from existing member states. Prospective candidates' relationships with member states can impact their accession prospects. EU enlargement is a political process requiring unanimous agreement from existing member states. A country's relationship with individual members can influence its EU accession prospects. The European Commission issues a formal opinion on an aspirant country, followed by a decision from the Council of Ministers. If all 28 member states agree, the country becomes an official EU candidate. EU enlargement process involves the European Commission issuing a formal opinion on an aspirant country, followed by a decision from the Council of Ministers. If all 28 member states agree, the country becomes an official EU candidate, leading to accession negotiations where the candidate must adopt EU treaties, laws, and regulations. The Commission and Council of Ministers must approve the opening of negotiations and a negotiating framework. The EU enlargement process involves the European Commission issuing a formal opinion on an aspirant country, followed by a decision from the Council of Ministers. If all 28 member states agree, the country becomes an official EU candidate. Accession negotiations then begin, where the candidate must adopt and implement EU treaties, laws, and regulations. The Commission and Council of Ministers must approve the opening of negotiations and a negotiating framework, which establishes guidelines for the talks. The EU's acquis communautaire, consisting of nearly 144,000 pages of rules and regulations divided into 35 chapters, covers various topics from free movement of goods to competition. Accession negotiations on each chapter start with a screening process. The EU's acquis communautaire consists of 144,000 pages of rules divided into 35 chapters covering topics like free movement of goods and competition. Accession negotiations on each chapter start with a screening process to assess the applicant's compliance. The European Commission proposes common negotiating positions for the EU on each chapter, and conducts detailed negotiations at the ministerial level to establish terms for adoption and implementation. The EU's acquis communautaire consists of 144,000 pages of rules divided into 35 chapters covering topics like free movement of goods and competition. Accession negotiations on each chapter start with a screening process to assess the applicant's compliance. The European Commission proposes common negotiating positions for the EU on each chapter, and conducts detailed negotiations at the ministerial level to establish terms for adoption and implementation. Enlargement policy and accession negotiations are directed and led by the EU Commissioner for Enlargement and European Neighborhood Policy, currently Stefan Füle. In all areas of the acquis, the candidate country must bring its institutions, management capacity, and administrative and judicial systems up to EU standards. During EU accession negotiations, the candidate country must align its institutions, management capacity, and systems with EU standards. Financial assistance is provided to aid in the accession process, and transition periods for complying with EU rules can be requested. Approval from all 28 EU member states is required to open and close chapters of the acquis. The EU provides financial assistance to candidate countries during accession negotiations. Approval from all 28 EU member states is needed to open and close chapters of the acquis. The Commission issues progress reports assessing achievements in candidate countries. Once negotiations on all 35 chapters are concluded, agreements are incorporated into a draft. The EU requires unanimous approval from all 28 member states for the accession process of candidate countries. The Commission issues progress reports to assess achievements, and once negotiations on all 35 chapters are completed, agreements are included in a draft accession treaty. This treaty must be approved by the Council of Ministers, the European Parliament, and ratified by each member state and the candidate country, a process that can take up to two years. Currently, five countries are official candidates for EU membership. Agreements reached in the accession process are included in a draft treaty, which needs approval from the Council of Ministers, European Parliament, and ratification from all EU member states and the candidate country. Currently, Iceland, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, and Turkey are official candidates for EU membership, each facing different challenges. Iceland has strong ties with the EU, including a free trade agreement dating back to 1972. Countries like Iceland, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, and Turkey are official candidates for EU membership. Iceland has close ties with the EU, including a free trade agreement since 1972 and membership in the European Economic Area (EEA) since 1994. Iceland participates in the EU's single market through the EEA and belongs to the Schengen area, allowing free movement within the EU. Iceland has been a member of the European Economic Area (EEA) since 1994, participating in the EU's single market. It also belongs to the Schengen area, allowing free movement within the EU. In 2009, Iceland applied for EU membership following the 2008 financial crisis. In July 2009, Iceland applied for EU membership after the 2008 financial crisis. Despite political divisions and citizen doubts, the government believed EU accession would help the country recover. Iceland was named an official candidate in June 2010 and began accession negotiations in July 2010. Iceland applied for EU membership in July 2009 to aid in economic recovery after the financial crisis. The EU named Iceland a candidate in June 2010 and started negotiations in July 2010. Talks have been on hold since May 2013. Iceland applied for EU membership in July 2009 for economic recovery after the financial crisis. Negotiations started in July 2010, with 27 of 35 chapters opened by the end of 2012. Talks have been on hold since May 2013 due to a new government opposed to EU membership. Iceland's future EU prospects are uncertain, with plans for a public referendum on resuming negotiations announced in 2013. The new center-right coalition government in Iceland is largely against EU membership. The government plans to hold a public referendum on whether to resume EU accession negotiations, but no date has been set yet. Opinion polls show strong opposition to EU membership in Iceland, especially as the economy improves. In February 2013, a report on Iceland's EU relations was presented to parliament, but no referendum date set. Strong opposition to EU membership in Iceland persists, especially with economic improvement. Challenges remain for Iceland in potential EU negotiations, including disputes over fisheries, whaling policies, and debts from the 2008 Icesave bank failure. Despite the challenges of resolving differences with the EU on fisheries and whaling policies, and settling debts from the 2008 Icesave bank failure, Iceland aims to resume accession negotiations in the future. Meanwhile, Macedonia, a former Yugoslav country, became an official EU candidate in 2005 after applying for membership in 2004. The European Commission has recommended opening membership talks with Macedonia. Macedonia, a former Yugoslav country, became an official EU candidate in 2005 after applying for membership in 2004. The European Commission has recommended opening membership talks with Macedonia since 2009, citing the country's fulfillment of political and economic criteria for EU membership. However, concerns have been raised about Macedonia's democratic progress and treatment of journalists and the media following a political crisis in late 2012-early 2013. The European Commission has recommended opening membership talks with Macedonia since 2009, citing the country's fulfillment of political and economic criteria for EU membership. Concerns remain about Macedonia's democratic progress, treatment of journalists, inter-ethnic tensions, and the need for reforms in the rule of law, freedom of expression, judiciary independence, and anti-corruption efforts. The EU urges Macedonia to complete necessary reforms for rule of law, freedom of expression, judiciary independence, and anti-corruption efforts. Concerns remain about inter-ethnic tensions, especially with the Albanian minority. Macedonia's accession negotiations are delayed due to a disagreement with Greece over its official name. Macedonia's EU accession negotiations are delayed due to a long-standing disagreement with Greece over its official name, with Greece blocking talks due to concerns about territorial claims. The EU currently refers to Macedonia as the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) in official documents. Greece's territorial dispute with Macedonia over its official name has led to delays in EU accession talks. The EU currently refers to Macedonia as FYROM in official documents. Bulgaria has also expressed concerns about Macedonia's readiness for EU membership. Several EU member states are hesitant to support opening accession due to political difficulties and declining democratic standards in Macedonia. Bulgaria's concerns about Macedonia's EU accession talks have led to a block, with other EU member states also hesitant due to political difficulties and declining democratic standards in the country. The European Commission initiated a High Level Accession Dialogue (HLAD) in 2012 to support Macedonia's reforms. The European Commission launched a High Level Accession Dialogue (HLAD) with Macedonia in 2012 to support reforms, but there are concerns about the stalled accession process risking the country's reform efforts. The HLAD has contributed to progress in priority areas, including court backlogs and corruption. Macedonia's formal accession process is stalled, risking reform efforts. Key challenges for Montenegro include improving the rule of law, fighting corruption, enhancing judiciary independence, guaranteeing freedom of expression, strengthening administrative capacity, and improving the business environment. EU officials acknowledge Montenegro's progress but emphasize the need for more work. Montenegro has made solid progress towards meeting EU standards, but more work is needed. Key challenges include improving the rule of law, fighting corruption and organized crime, enhancing judiciary independence, guaranteeing freedom of expression, strengthening administrative capacity, and improving the business environment. EU member states and officials had difficult relations with Serbia in the past due to its responsibility for the violent dissolution of the former Yugoslavia and the conflict over Kosovo. Serbian-EU relations were historically strained due to Serbia's role in the dissolution of Yugoslavia and the conflict over Kosovo. The EU criticized Serbia for being slow to implement reforms, uncooperative in tracking down war crimes suspects, and resistant to normalizing relations with Kosovo. Serbia has made progress in modernizing its political and economic system, signing a Stabilization and Association Agreement with the EU in 2008 and applying for EU membership in 2009. Serbia has made significant progress in modernizing its political and economic system, signing a Stabilization and Association Agreement with the EU in 2008 and applying for EU membership in 2009. In 2011, Serbia's accession prospects improved after the arrest and extradition of war crimes suspects, leading to a recommendation for EU candidate status by the European Commission. In 2011, Serbia's EU accession prospects improved significantly after the arrest and extradition of war crimes suspects. The European Commission recommended EU candidate status for Serbia in October 2011, contingent on improving relations with Kosovo. In February 2012, Serbia reached agreements with Kosovo on key EU concerns, including Kosovo's participation in regional institutions and border management. In February 2012, Serbia concluded accords with Kosovo addressing key EU concerns, allowing Kosovo to participate in regional institutions and jointly manage the border. As a result, the EU named Serbia an official candidate in March 2012, with talks between Serbia and Kosovo continuing under EU auspices. In December 2012, EU leaders agreed to consider opening negotiations with Serbia in spring 2013, pending a Commission report on Serbia's progress towards meeting EU membership criteria. In April 2013, Serbia and Kosovo reached a landmark agreement on normalizing relations, focusing on resolving the situation in Northern Kosovo, which is predominantly ethnic Serbian and under de facto control of Belgrade. In April 2013, Serbia and Kosovo reached a landmark agreement on normalizing relations, with a focus on resolving the situation in Northern Kosovo, which is mostly ethnic Serbian and under de facto control of Belgrade. In December 2013, EU member states endorsed opening accession talks with Serbia, meeting all EU membership criteria. EU governments wanted additional time to assess progress on the implementation of the Serbia-Kosovo agreement before setting a firm start date for accession talks. In June 2013, the EU announced it would open accession negotiations with Serbia by January 2014 at the latest. EU member states endorsed opening accession talks with Serbia in December 2013, noting Serbia's compliance with membership criteria and improvement of relations with Kosovo. The EU endorsed opening accession talks with Serbia in late January 2014, noting Serbia's compliance with membership criteria and improvement of relations with Kosovo. Serbia was urged to continue efforts in various areas such as rule of law, judiciary reform, fighting corruption, protecting minority rights, and enhancing the business environment. However, Serbia is not expected to join the EU until at least 2020. The EU urged Serbia to continue efforts in improving rule of law, judiciary reform, fighting corruption, protecting minority rights, and enhancing the business environment. Serbia may not join the EU until 2020 at the earliest, and some experts suggest that Kosovo's independence status must be resolved before Serbia's admission. Turkey's EU membership bid has faced historical challenges. Some experts suggest that the EU may not admit Serbia until Kosovo's independence status is resolved. Turkey's bid for EU membership has faced challenges due to concerns about its political system, human rights record, economy, and large Muslim population. Tensions exist among EU member states regarding Turkey's membership application. Turkey's EU membership aspirations date back to the 1960s when an association agreement was signed with the European Economic Community. Despite support from EU member states, concerns over Turkey's political system, human rights record, economy, and Muslim population have led to divisions within the Union. The status of Turkey's membership application remains a source of tension between Turkey and the EU. Turkey's EU aspirations date back to the 1960s with the Ankara Agreement in 1963, leading to a customs union in 1995. Despite being declared eligible for EU membership in 1997, Turkey's application was essentially rejected in 1987. In 1970, Turkey began preparing for a customs union with the European Community. In 1995, the customs union between the EU and Turkey was established, allowing goods to cross the border without restrictions. Turkey hoped for a firm date to start EU negotiations in 2002 but was disappointed. Despite significant reforms, concerns remained about meeting membership criteria and stance on Cyprus. Despite significant reforms, concerns remained about Turkey's stance on Cyprus, which has been divided since 1974. Turkish troops are stationed in northern Cyprus, and Turkey does not recognize the Republic of Cyprus under the Greek Cypriot government. In December 2004, the EU stated that Turkey had made enough progress for accession talks to begin. Turkey met EU requirements for accession talks in 2005 by enacting reform legislation and extending agreements to include Cyprus. Turkey met EU requirements for accession talks in 2005 by enacting reform legislation and extending agreements to include Cyprus, despite some debate over diplomatic recognition of the Greek Cypriot government. In July 2005, Turkey pledged to extend its EU agreements and customs union without granting diplomatic recognition to the Greek Cypriot government. Despite contentious debate among EU members, accession talks with Turkey began in October 2005. The EU stated that negotiations aim for accession but the outcome is uncertain, leaving full membership for Turkey not guaranteed. The EU opened accession talks with Turkey in October 2005, aiming for eventual full membership but with no guarantee. Negotiations on the acquis started in 2006, with slow progress due to Cyprus-related issues. Turkey's refusal to open ports and airports has complicated the process. Negotiations between the EU and Turkey on full membership began in 2006, with slow progress due to Cyprus-related issues. Turkey's refusal to open ports and airports to the Greek Cypriot part of the island has hindered talks on 14 chapters of the acquis. EU delayed opening eight chapters affecting the customs union until Turkey complies with the Additional Protocol for Cyprus. Turkey's refusal to open its ports and airports to ships and planes from the Greek Cypriot part of the island, as required by the 1970 Additional Protocol and the customs union, is a major obstacle in EU-Turkey membership negotiations. The EU has delayed opening eight chapters related to the customs union until Turkey complies with the Additional Protocol for Cyprus. Cyprus and France also maintain holds on opening other chapters of the acquis. In May 2012, the European Commission launched a "positive agenda" with Turkey to reinvigorate EU-Turkish relations and inject new momentum into Turkey's accession process. Areas covered included alignment of Turkish legislation with the EU acquis and political reforms. In May 2012, the European Commission launched a "positive agenda" with Turkey to reinvigorate EU-Turkish relations and inject new momentum into Turkey's accession process. Areas covered by the agenda included alignment of Turkish legislation with the EU acquis, political reforms, visas, energy, and counterterrorism. The agenda was intended to complement and support Turkey's accession process, with the exception of negotiations for visa-free travel for Turks throughout the EU within three years. The EU launched a "positive agenda" with Turkey in 2012 to boost EU-Turkish relations and support Turkey's accession process. The agenda covered alignment with EU acquis, political reforms, visas, energy, and counterterrorism. However, it is unclear if the agenda has been successful or is still in operation.
